bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, September 24, 1894

div1.p: Carter describes a hurricane and notes the resulting damage it caused. His quarantine work is slackening and he thinks there will be no additional cases of yellow fever. He writes that he would rather be farming, but that he realizes he must stay with his current vocation.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, September 24, 1894
div1.p:
I presume we are having very near a hurricane
at last a heavy storm. Blowing about as it did
in S. Island in /88: not like the Gale of last October
at Chandeleur. It really isn't as strong as that in /88
because one can stand up in this wind & in that one
could not at times. Still it is a good wind.

We have 3 convalescents & two attendants on Bird Key in tents, to whom we
cannot get to day. The tents were still standing when we could last see them.
I wish they were up here: but we can't help it. They are safe enough.
as are we, I think Laura finds it a comfort to know that we
are on a rock foundation & have a 40 foot wall around
us. We have everything as secure as we can make it & one
just waiting. What we will lose we will lose. And the
glop keeps falling. If it wasn't that we have a shower tied
to the wharf. I would not greatly mind: but the wharf,
what is in it cost about $40,000.00/100, I am uneasy about it.
It is more wind than we had while you were with us
at Chandeleur: Indeed it is I suppose a hurricane.

We have been well, same Laura: She has
not been so well, although not laid up nor have I felt
well, still I am not sick. The children are very well &
I believe Henry is getting quite strong again.
We keep our quota of repels, although the work is pre-
ciptibly letting up now, we came in yesterday, just in
time. We are not apt to get any man Y. F. & I do hope
we will not. Still it is not too late

What I will do this winter I do not know. I am
waiting to hear from Mr Thornton to whom I wrote about
Dr Dabney's place. I would not be surprised if I stayed here
until March & really would not greatly mind it. The
children would escape the various colds & sore throats
which make winter so detectable: It isn't a good life I
had human: & I wish for my own sake I was farming in the country.
However I must stay in the vacation I am

If I can get north this year. & come any where near
you I will came to North River for 10 or 15 days, My
two flying visits were too brief to be counted. in the
This is a storm beyond all doubt & I judge from
the wreck of the cocoä nut trees that it is the hea-
viest from this direction for some years.
Give my love to all at home & at Hill's.

Your affectionate son
H. R. Carter

25: night: It was a hurricane- The spray has run over the fort &
but that we lost all of our gutters early in the action. had
ruined all the drinking water in the fort. One could not see 100 y'ds
for the spray & rain. The fort of course protected us & we were never in
any danger, but even in the fort the grass is in places whipped to
The sea broke over the break water stored, the fort like battering rams,
pierced. outside the little cedars are all pealed. & bare of bark.
It was grand will & had I not been worried about the find Key
proper, to whom I could not get, I had enjoyed it. I manned a ship's
boat, with 4 oars & two men to an oar & brought them off this
afternoon, The memoirs good condition. Had been under the yard
up in the bushes & had plenty of blankets. We lost nothing.
$5.00 will pay for the damage the floating raft sustained. The
buildings however, suffered a good deal & what it will cost to re-
pair them I scarcely know not over $1000.00 however,The treas
take them. I say a hurricane. It was no hurricane like some
that we have had. like that of Oct 2,/93 for instance to that at St. Thomas,
